speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.1: COVID Mask Policy - The board will discuss the district’s COVID-19 health protocols, specifically whether students should be required to wear masks while in classrooms. This policy would apply during the regular school day, with exceptions for lunch and designated mask-break periods. The goal is to balance student safety with comfort and learning effectiveness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I'll go first. Thank you, Graham Paige. As we all know, this has been an ongoing topic since last year when schools reopened after lockdowns. Our current guidelines follow state recommendations but allow teachers discretion over masking within their own rooms. We've had some concerns from parents about inconsistent enforcement across classes and buildings. So my question today is what kind of data do our administrators have regarding transmission rates among staff and students both masked and unmasked environments? Have there been any incidents where contact tracing showed classroom spread occurred because someone wasn't wearing a face covering properly? What does science tell us at present about how much protection these coverings provide indoors versus outdoors? And finally, can we hear more details around logistics such as supply chain management if we were

speaker: grahampaige
content: Okay, thank you Ms. Acuff. Dr. McLaughlin could answer your questions related to those statistics. Are they available right now so far as transmissions between masked and non-masked areas? Or maybe even just general information about cases throughout the county compared to other counties who may have different policies than ours?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I'd also appreciate it, Doctor, if you could share any insights into the impact of mask-wearing on our younger learners' social-emotional development and academic performance. Some educators have expressed concern that prolonged use might hinder facial recognition skills, impede emotional intelligence, and create anxiety issues. Can you enlighten us on research findings addressing these specific aspects?

speaker: grahampaige
content: OK, thanks very much Ellen Osborne. Other comments before Dr. Haas responds? All right, Dr. Haas please proceed.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I'm going to say something real quick too. If we're talking about making sure kids feel comfortable then let them take off their masks outside period point blank. That way no one gets upset. But inside, yes keep 'em on until further notice. It makes me uncomfortable seeing people walking down hallways without anything on. You don't see adults doing that anywhere except here.

speaker: davidoberg
content: My main issue lies in consistency. Inconsistencies breed confusion which leads directly to frustration amongst faculty members, pupils, and guardians alike. How exactly did administration plan out implementing uniformity concerning teacher autonomy vs centralized control given differing opinions on efficacy?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Forgive me; I didn’t catch everything said earlier due to technical difficulties. However, based upon listening carefully thusfar, I think perhaps instead of focusing solely on mandating masks universally everywhere every time, why couldn't we explore alternative measures aimed towards mitigating risks associated with airborne pathogens spreading through ventilation systems by investing in air purification units installed strategically throughout each building campuswide? These devices remove particles including viruses effectively enough according to studies published recently. They seem quite promising. Would love input on feasibility cost-wise along with potential benefits. Thanks!

speaker: judyle
content: Hi everyone, Judy Le speaking. I want to piggyback on Katrina Callisen's comment about outdoor spaces. While allowing students to remove masks outside seems reasonable, shouldn't we consider setting up supervised stations near playground equipment or sports fields where kids can briefly shed their masks under adult supervision? Perhaps designate certain zones exclusively for eating snacks/lunches sans masks? By creating structured breaks, we ensure better compliance overall. Thoughts?

speaker: kateacuff
content: KateAcuff here again. To build onto Jon Noel Carro's suggestion, wouldn't installing HEPA filters make sense especially considering long-term investment value beyond pandemic times? Could Dr. Mclaughlan give his thoughts on incorporating similar solutions alongside updated HVAC infrastructure upgrades already planned? Also, I wonder aloud ––if indeed proven effective––wouldn't upgrading indoor air quality justify reevaluation of strictness surrounding universal masking mandates later on?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Ah, excellent points raised by several colleagues! Building on JudyLe's idea, having supervised mask-free zones sounds feasible, ensuring accountability while giving children brief respites. Additionally, exploring alternatives like air purifiers and upgraded filtration systems resonates strongly with me. Before revisiting mask mandates, I believe we must exhaustively examine evidence-based strategies promoting healthier indoor environments. Has our facilities team assessed costs and implementation timelines for integrating these technologies into existing infrastructures, Dr. Haas?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I guess another thing would be, though - I mean, I understand the importance of being able to read faces during class discussions, et cetera. Maybe offer optional clear shields rather than cloth ones. At least that way, you still get visual cues yet maintain safety protocols. Just throwing ideas out there.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thank goodness some common-sense suggestions finally entered this discussion. Implementing strategic mitigation methods such as advanced air-purification technology is an avenue worth pursuing seriously. We should definitely look at both short- and long-term financial implications but weigh against health concerns simultaneously. As well, offering transparent face coverings does deserve consideration since reading body language plays significant roles within educational settings. Let’s hear more from experts regarding practicalities involved.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: And thank all who've contributed so far because they really do resonate deeply with my own sentiments. Now moving forward, what kind of timeline may we expect when reassessing current policies once data becomes available after winter holidays? Are we looking toward spring semester adjustments potentially? Or will changes come sooner depending on local transmission rates dropping significantly? What metrics guide your decision-making process specifically, Dr.Hass?

speaker: judyle
content: Absolutely agree with David Oberg's sentiment that it's high time we started discussing pragmatic approaches. The notion of weighing budgetary constraints versus student welfare has been lingering beneath the surface. Given the array of innovative proposals presented today, might I suggest forming a subcommittee comprising representatives from various departments—facilities management, education specialists, medical advisors—to delve deeper into researching viable options, crunch numbers, and provide actionable recommendations for future policy revisions? This collaborative effort could help us strike a balance between fiscal responsibility and prioritizing healthy learning environments. Who'd be willing to join forces on this endeavor?

speaker: kateacuff
content: So glad others share enthusiasm around proactive steps addressing environmental factors contributing to infection spread. A task force dedicated to investigating multi-faceted interventions feels timely now. Count me among those eager participants ready to collaborate across disciplines. Can someone clarify whether any preliminary research exists detailing successful implementations elsewhere, either nationally or internationally, showcasing best practices applicable locally?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Excellent suggestions keep pouring in! Forming a multidisciplinary committee makes perfect sense, JudyLe. It'll allow us to tackle this complex challenge holistically. I wholeheartedly support the proposal and volunteer myself to participate. Having diverse perspectives will undoubtedly enrich our findings and inform sound decisions.

Regarding previous successes, KateAcuff, I recall attending conferences highlighting schools abroad adopting cutting-edge ventilation systems and witnessing remarkable reductions in absenteeism related to respiratory issues. Our research subgroup could certainly investigate further, gathering case studies and expert insights to bolster our approach.

Dr. Hass, if possible, please update us on the availability of relevant resources, expertise, and potential partnerships that could aid our investigation. With collective efforts, I'm confident we're heading down a path

speaker: grahampaige
content: Okay, thanks very much Ellen Osborne. Any other comments before we move ahead? If none then let's go back over to Mr. McLaughlin.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thanks, Graham Paige. One last thought: When reviewing cost-benefit analyses associated with implementing new measures, remember how crucial teacher retention remains amid ongoing stressors. Investing upfront in staff wellness initiatives directly correlates to improved morale which trickles down positively impacting academic performance ultimately benefiting every stakeholder group present tonight. Keep holistic thinking front-and-center throughout deliberations going forth. That said, appreciate everybody sharing valuable input thusfar; excitedly await next updates.

speaker: grahampaige
content: OKAY, THANK YOU SO MUCH KATRINA CALLSEN FOR THAT REMARK AS WELL. AND NOW WE'LL GO BACK TO MR. MC LAUGHLIN WITH OUR NEXT ITEM ON THE AGENDA.

speaker: davidoberg
content: You know, KatrinaCallsen hit upon something vital just now – teachers’ mental wellbeing matters profoundly amidst pandemic-related pressures. In tandem with infrastructure upgrades, allocating funds towards supporting educators emotionally can have profound effects cascading onto students too. To echo her point succinctly, investing early pays dividends later through enhanced job satisfaction translating into better outcomes overall.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I think one final comment was made by DaveOberg about keeping track of COVID cases amongst faculty members. Is there anything like that currently happening where we’re tracking positive tests amongst employees also? Because while yes, kids bring germs home sometimes, adults interact closely together often times without masks especially outside classrooms.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Yes indeed, Katrinas observation resonates strongly here - monitoring employee infections would give administrators critical insight into workplace transmissions dynamics. By doing so, targeted strategies focused on adult-to-adult contact points become feasible. Has HR implemented internal reporting mechanisms allowing personnel to confidentially disclose their status, thereby facilitating informed response planning?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Thank you both again. We did discuss at an earlier meeting having some sort of mechanism set up within human resource department whereby folks were able to report voluntarily but still maintain confidentiality regarding testing results. But perhaps Ms. Acuff could follow-up more definitively on exactly what is being done right now along these lines.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Ah, thank you, GrahamPaige. Indeed, voluntary self-reporting channels do exist via Human Resources presently ensuring privacy protection. However, considering heightened concerns voiced during this session, revisiting protocols may prove beneficial. Perhaps DrHass could explore refining current procedures alongside district health experts to guarantee seamless communication flows when dealing with infected staffers. What adjustments should we make moving forward given evolving circumstances?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: And it seems pretty clear from all your responses that everyone wants to see change happen quickly. The question becomes who gets involved in making sure that happens effectively. Would each person be willing to serve on such a subcommittee exploring ways to address indoor air quality improvements, because time truly does matter?

content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.1: Should the district require students to wear masks in classrooms during the school day?.  If each of you could please record your vote in the chat, I will tally them up and announce the results.
